metadata.label: Condition
metadata.value:
The papyrus is broken off on all four sides. The papyrus fibres are frayed on the sides and in many places the fibres have gotten lose or have disappeared causing lacunae in the text.
The bottom half of the papyrus on the recto is covered by mud making the writing illegible. Some lines on the verso are partially crossed out. The text is incomplete on all sides.

metadata.label: Personal names
metadata.value: ʿUmar b. ʿAwf; ʿAmr b. al-ʿĀṣ; ʿUmar b. al-Khaṭṭāb; Hishām

metadata.label: Further remarks
metadata.value:
This anecdote is preserved in Ibn ʿAbd al-Ḥakam's (d. 870) Futuḥ Miṣr; Muqaddasi, BGA 3, 207; Ibn Faqīh, Kitāb al-buldān, BGA 5, 65-6. 
 
Reserved by P.M. Sijpesteijn.

metadata.label: Content description
metadata.value: Historical text relating several events from the early Islamic history of Egypt. On the recto a version of the story that after the conquest of Egypt ʿAmr b. al-ʿĀṣ abolished the Coptic custom to sacrifice a virgin slavegirl (l. 6) to the Nile river in the month Ba'una to ensure the rising of the water. When  ʿAmr heard of this custom he prohibited announcing that "Islam abolishes everything that preceded it." When the Nile water did not rise that year, ʿAmr wrote the caliph ʿUmar b. al-Khaṭṭāb who subsequently wrote a letter to the Nile ordering it to rise its waters as it was God who made its waters rise. The version in the papyrus diverges at some points from the version known to us from that preserved in the literary sources.
